segments.text: So as far as you were concerned, then the campus ought to be located as close to Scripps as possible.
That's right.

And the alternative, as I say, was that they would put the School of Science and Engineering here on the 50 acres of land the city had given them and put the university somewhere else, the big new university campus.
But I had several reasons for thinking this.
One was that I thought it would be good for the Scripps Institution.
Another was that the beautiful site was by far the most handsome site in the whole area.
And the third was that the existence of the Scripps Institution would give credibility to the whole enterprise.
This was a great place and a well-known, worldwide known place, so it would be easier to recruit faculty.
Now, the great antagonist of this position was one of the regents, a man named Ed Pauley.
Ed who?
Pauley, P-A-U-L-E-Y.
Okay.
And he just really didn't want to have a campus in San Diego at all.
He never actually said that because other regents were pretty enthusiastic about it.
And it would have been counterproductive, from his political point of view, it would have been counterproductive to mount a frontal attack on the new campus.
So he proposed that it be in Balboa Park.
Balboa Park is the crown jewel of San Diego, sort of like Golden Gate Park in San Francisco.
And the people of San Diego wouldn't give it up for anything, let alone for the university, because they don't understand.
So that was just obviously a ploy on his part.
The second ploy was after it was more or less agreed by, it was not agreed, but I was enthusiastic about it, and quite a few other people were to have it there where it is now.
The second ploy was that the airplane noise level would be too high because of the Miramar Naval Air Station.
My assistant director was a man named Charles Wheelock.
Charles DeLorma Wheelock, retired admiral, Bureau of Ships type admiral, naval constructor.
Kind of a funny guy to have an associate director of an oceanographic institution, but he just got seasick looking at the ocean.
That's why he was a naval architect and not a line officer.
But he was a
An absolutely wonderful man.
Modest, decent, honest, persuasive, bright, good guy.
And I was just awfully lucky to con the Navy into letting me have him.
Letting him retire early, come out here to script.
I'd worked on this for years, getting him.
And he was able to talk the people at Miramar into changing their flight patterns.

instead of flying directly over Scripps, as they had done on their takeoff, they turned and made a sharp right turn and flew out over Torrey Pines Park, Torrey Pines State, that canyon between Torrey Pines and Del Mar, which is pretty hard on a General Dynamics laboratory, a General Atomics laboratory.
It flew right over them.
But
We then, Jeff Crouchy particularly, measured lots of noise levels all over the Bose campus, and we showed that they were not really very bad.
And we looked up other campuses that were under a flight pattern, like the University of Minnesota, and the University of Arizona, and the Riverside campus at the University of California.
They all seemed to be getting along.
But Paulie's a very
serious fighter when he gets involved with something.
He took the Regents out to his estate on Coconut Island in the middle of Kaneohe Bay in Milwaukee.
And about two miles from his house there, his estate, is a marine air station.
And he got the commandant of that station to fly a flight of
fighter planes right over his house at about 200 feet and turn off their afterburners, just as they got over the house.
And this scared the Regis to death, as you can imagine.
It's like an explosion.
It was awful.
Pereira was a very good guy, Del Pereira.
Charles Luckman was a former president of the Lieber Brothers and essentially a social.
He also had a degree in architecture, I guess.
But he was basically a salesman.
And by this time, they had split up after this search had been going on for years over a new campus.
And Luckman, being a very political type and knowing that Poly was the most powerful region, found all sorts of reasons why we shouldn't have the campus here.
He said it might cost $20 million more for noise protection.
Unfortunately, he was also the architect for the Scripps Memorial Hospital, which had a site about two miles closer to Miramar than we were and much closer to the flight pad as we were.
And he wrote a letter to the administrator of the hospital saying that airplane noise would be no problem at this new site for the hospital.
And the administrator said, one of the advantages of living in a place a long time is you get to know a lot of people pretty well.
The administrator gave me a copy of this letter.
It wasn't confidential, but I gave it to Clark Kerr.
We had another meeting at Davis.
This was about 1960, 1959, I guess.
Ferreira and Luckman got up and told us about all this terrible noise problem here by the site.
And Clark said, well, it's very interesting, but I have a letter here from you.
You wrote to the administrator of the Scripps Hospital.
There wouldn't be any noise about it.
Oh, my.
And the upshot was that the regents voted.
Well, there were two upshots.
One was that the regents voted 21 to 1 to locate the site in La Jolla.
The other upshot was that I never became chancellor.
was a period victory as far as I was concerned.
I was the dean of the School of Science and Engineering.
It's a paper organization.
I was chief campus officer.
I was responsible for making the plan, the academic plan for the university and recruiting people for it.
So we had several principles, several ideas.
The regions put all sorts of conditions on having this site here.
One of the conditions was they should get 1,200 acres of land free and clear from somebody.

Another condition was that there should be a university town, a university community built up and planned by the city in cooperation with the regents, with the Office of Architects and Engineers of the university.
I think, I don't remember what other conditions there were, but those were the principles, the university plan, the plan for the region, and the land free and clear.
So we had a campaign, a political campaign in San Diego, which the city of San Diego voted to give us something like
800 acres of land, Pueblo land, the same kind of land I told you about before, right next to the Scripps, with 180 acres of the Scripps Institution.
I've forgotten the exact number.
Maybe it was only 600.
It was quite a large chunk of land.
And then we started to work on the Marine Corps.
Charles Wheelock, of course, contributed to the omen service there.
The Marine Corps really had to move because they were such a nuisance.
It was a Marine Corps rifle range called Camp Matthews.
And eventually, we got from the Navy.
The Navy agreed to turn over Camp Matthews to the University.
We got 1,200 acres of land clear.
And they also, the city cooperated handsomely
in the planning of the whole region because of something called University City, and they now have a university town planned just east of the campus.

The second idea was that, besides this first idea that it ought to be here, the second idea was that it ought to be primarily a research university, not necessarily primarily, but a strong emphasis on research and graduate instruction.
And that therefore, it had to have outstanding research people.
And that the way we would do this would be to build up one department at a time to critical mass.
We would not start out with a faculty, an undergraduate faculty covering the waterfront.
We would have just one department necessary to begin with, and another one, and another one.
Each one good enough.
of first-rate researchers in it to have a good doctoral program and a good chance of getting support for research from the federal government.
They would support each other in ideas and in inspiration.
That intellectual exchange is quite essential for research.
Clark Kerr backed that wholeheartedly.
So we did just that, and I got three people who were brilliant academic recruiters and organizers.
Jim Arnold in chemistry, Keith Brooker in physics, and David Bonner in biology.
They were all thrilled with the idea of building a new university, and with the idea that we'd do it this way and not simply
Start from the bottom and build up.
Start from the top and go down.
Build a roof first, as we used to call it.
And they all had a whole list of first grade people that they knew, many of whom were young and not very well known.
They thought it would be good to have here, and they all went to town and persuaded them.
Iowa, of course, did a great deal of this.
In a sense, everybody that would come here, we had a kind of a routine.
We would talk about our ideas at the new university.
And we'd draw diagrams, and we'd talk about the idea they were going to tell you about in a minute.
And I'd take people up and show them where the campus was going to be.
There was a pile on it that they left over from the days when it was an Army camp.
There was a pillar that supported the roof, and it was still standing there.
And there was a fallen chimney right next to it.
I'd get people to stand on top of this fallen chimney, and you could see it for about two miles in every direction.
It was quite a sight.
And we'd always have a party for them, and get the most interesting people we could find at this party.
Everybody thought this was a dull place, and it was a dull place.
But there were some interesting people here.
A lot of people got excited about it.
Of course, the more we got, the more we got.
It was snowballing.
One of our prime recruiting grounds was the University of Chicago.
The reason for that was that Bob Hutchings, Bob Resting, had let the neighborhood deteriorate.
It had become the center of a black ghetto.
And these blacks were all played rough, played very rough.
dangerous for a white man or a white woman to go out on the streets, even in the daytime, alone at night.
So that's one of the principal reasons why Harold Urey came here, Harold and Freda Urey.
And then we got Joe Mayer and his wife, Maria Mayer, later, after she came here, won a Nobel Prize from the University of Chicago.
Several other people.
Bonner himself came from Yale and Brooker from the University of Pennsylvania.
And Brooker emphasized mainly solid state physics.
He got half a dozen top people in solid state physics.
That was essentially a new field.
There were Matias and Harry Sewell and
Walter Cohn were three of them.
Then you got Norman Crowe, theoretical physicist.
He himself is a theoretical nuclear physicist.
And most of these people were between 30 and 40 years old.
Any of them worked for the Bell Labs.
That was another prime recruit down there.
I had a principal, quote, principal, end quote.
He would not pay anybody a higher salary than the salary he was getting where he was.
on the theory that if you could buy people, somebody else could buy them away from you.
Well, that's a high-sounding theory, all right.
The fact is that people who came here from the Bell Labs just about doubled their salary because they were able to consult here in the summertime.
Working for the Bell Labs, if they got $23,000 a year, pretty good salary.
That's all they got.
They couldn't consult at all.
Here, if they got it, we offered them $23,000.
Now you're $15,000, $20,000 in the summertime consulting.
So really, Keith never told me this.
But I found out.
I eventually caught on.
Keith was always in favor of paying people as much as you could possibly pay.
This was his principle.
It wasn't a question of stealing people or buying them.
It was a question that they deserved a high income.
They were good physicists.
That's what good physicists should have, is high income.
And we got some very good people in the earth sciences, some very good people in biology, very good people in both chemistry and physics.
Proof of the pudding is that now, 15 years later, something like 45 members of the National Academy of Sciences are on this campus.
That's the only two or three universities in the country that have a higher number.
Harvard has.
The University of California at Berkeley has.
And that's about it.
Or Rockefeller University.
Jet Bronk and I used to compare notes all the time.
He wanted to do what I, he was doing what I really would have liked to do, but couldn't do.
Building up primarily a small graduate school.
They've got Nobel Prize winners running out over here at Rockefeller University.
Every other guy you see is a Nobel Prize winner.
And they're all members of the National Academy of Science.
But you know, we did pretty well under the circumstances.
And the most important thing that I did, without really realizing it, was to find a first rate library.
I was pushed hard on that by people who come from regular universities.
So I would back places like the Scripps Institution.
They thought a library was very important.
And it is very important.
It's terribly important.

We got a man from Kent, a librarian at the University of Kent, named Mel Boyd, who's built up really an impossible job of building up a pretty good library here in 15 years with very inadequate resources.
Got well over a million volumes.
about a million and a half.
It's divided into five different libraries, the Central Library, the Science and Engineering Library, the Scripps Institution Library, the Undergraduate Library, and the Medical, Biomedical Library.
Each of these is a model of organization and management and service, plus having the books and the journals.
The way I got started on this was that
when it was planned to have these three new campuses, he volunteered to collect an undergraduate library for all three of them in duplicate.
Since he was on the ground and the other two campuses had really gotten started yet.
We were started because we had scripts.
He did just that.
He got 75,000 volumes in triplicate.
He gave one to Santa Cruz, one to Irvine, and we have one here.
The Regents were so impressed by this that for a few years they gave him almost everything he wanted by the university administration.
The second chancellor here was a man named John Galbraith.
And he was a historian and very much
aware of the necessity of a research library for humanists, more so for humanists than either for natural scientists or social scientists.
So he pushed the library very hard, too.
Clark Kerr was his longtime friend, and he got Clark quite sympathetic with it, too.
Unfortunately, Clark got fired.
Clark used to say, I entered my job and left it the same way, fired with enthusiasm.
But the thing which we used to attract people, the idea we used to attract people, and it was a very good idea.
We really had three ideas.
One of them was that we would divide the place up into colleges, not Oxbridge-type small colleges,
primarily undergraduate teaching institutions, but essentially little universities side by side, universities of about 2,000 students.
And we plan to have 12 of them, 2,000 25-minute students, 1 third of graduates and 2 thirds undergraduates.
It's a mix, I thought.
And the reason for this was that each college could be semi-autonomous, could provide a liberal education in all branches
of human thought.
And at the same time, the faculty would be small enough so they could think and act, and not only react, which is the way it was at Berkeley, because the faculty was so goddamn big.
Berkeley has traditionally been run by the faculty, but they don't really run it.
You never get any ideas put across.
It's impossible to experiment with a faculty of 3,000 people or something.
Well, my idea was to have maybe 150 to 200 people as the faculty of each of these little universities.
And they would be able to sneak up their own curriculum and their own requirements and their own programs.
And they would be different.
You'd be sure that they were different by the kind of people you get for each one.
The first college I thought of as essentially a place to produce graduate students.
In other words, a scholarly place.
Not just in science, but in humanities and social sciences as well as in natural sciences.
I thought of the second one as perhaps a place to produce artists and people related to artists, like architects, journalists, writers.
The third college would be perhaps a graduate school
a school of business administration, a fourth maybe a school of law, undergraduate, pushed in that direction towards administration or government.
And you could have a somewhat different set of departments in each one.
Each set of departments, however, would cover the waterfront of human knowledge.
And one you'd have, say, traditional biology.
This would be the one that emphasized art.
Because the great motivation of the traditional biologist
It's beauty.
It's the aesthetics of organisms.
In our first college, the graduate school college, we'd have high-powered experimental biology.
So it's different when we have ecology, applied biology, leading towards, say, government management.
You have different kinds of earth science.
There's different kinds of physics, solid state physics in one, theoretical physics in another, hydrodynamics in a third, and so forth.
Well, this didn't work out, but it sounded good.
And everybody, all professors traditionally deplored apartments.
They're enthusiastic about multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary studies on paper.
In fact, they don't give a damn about interdisciplinary or multidisciplinary studies.
And they love departments, as you know.
But they thought it would be nice to try it the other way.
My second idea was that we should emphasize creativity
in the arts rather than criticism.

In other words, we have musicians and painters and actors and playwrights and scene and stage designers and sculptors and composers and musicians, performing musicians, not people who wrote about what other people did in the arts.
In other words, our humanities would be the complement of the sciences in the sense that they would be creative rather than critical.
One of the reasons for that was we didn't have much of a library.
It couldn't be very critical.
Third idea was that we'd mix up the graduates and the undergraduates.
The undergraduates would get in contact with research just as soon as they possibly could.
Because I said, and Glenn Seaborg said, and many of us agree, that the object of a college education is to learn how to learn, not to learn something, but to learn how to learn.
Because times are changing so fast, nothing that you learn makes much sense 10 years later.
So therefore, we would try to get the undergraduates involved with research, and we wanted to get the graduates involved with breadth
of learning that you get with contact with the humanities and the social sciences if you're in the natural sciences.
Not necessarily in courses, but in seminars and informal activities.
So we wanted to have each college have a mix of graduates and undergraduates.
Well, I guess none of these ideas have really worked out exactly.
colleges have turned out to be places that are primarily different in their undergraduate curriculum.
And they do have some differences in the undergraduate curriculum.
And the students think it's great to belong to a college.
As far as I can make out, they do.
That's what the faculty members tell me.
But as far as the graduates mixing with the undergraduates are concerned, that just doesn't happen very much.
The departments are university-wide departments.
They don't belong to the college.
They belong to the university.
They serve all the colleges, and they have a life of their own.
It is true that we have a lot of creative art here.
Not necessarily a good thing.
Because the creative artists are all wild artists, as you can imagine.
That's what art nowadays amounts to, is something most people don't understand.
The one idea that did work out pretty well, and very well, in fact, was the idea of building from the top down and building department by department.
And we have a series of very good departments, not necessarily very broad departments.
For example, our economists are all econometricians.
Now, God knows what econometricians do in the modern world, but that's what our guys do anyhow.
And our psychologists are all experimental psychologists.
Nevertheless, they're good.
We have a group of young, enthusiastic political scientists and a group of anthropologists.
I think we've failed in linguistics, more or less.
I'm not sure we're very good in comparative literature.
We're very good in basic sciences.
Pretty good in mathematics.
I guess fair in philosophy.
I'm not sure about that.
And so I guess that the only thing that really
is a sort of a permanent relic or a permanent residue of these great ideas is the college, is the university's physical structure.
The dormitories and the academic buildings for each college are right together.
And we have three of, four of them now.
Revelle College, your college, what's called third college, what's called fourth.
